content: <@!476250636548308992> https://github.com/ethereum/eth2.0-specs/blob/v0.11.3/configs/mainnet.yaml#L41

author: paulhauner
content: So AFAIK the spec isn‚Äôt clear as to wether we follow genesis deposits at the follow distance or not (not at PC, can‚Äôt verify)

author: paulhauner
content: The spec has the genesis delay set such that it doesn‚Äôt matter

author: nishant0
content: the spec doesn't define the follow distance for genesis deposits

author: paulhauner
content: But if the genesis delay is less than the follow distance then there‚Äôs an issue

author: donschoe
content: ok so which client is correct then?

author: paulhauner
content: IMO we should follow at the distance. It‚Äôs there to protect against reorgs, why shouldn‚Äôt that count at genesis too?

author: paulhauner
content: If we don‚Äôt follow genesis at the same follow distance as voting then we get this odd jump in time too, potentially invalidating some deposits

author: nishant0
content:
the spec defines it only using the genesis delay, not the follow distance 
```py
        genesis_time=eth1_timestamp - eth1_timestamp % MIN_GENESIS_DELAY + 2 * MIN_GENESIS_DELAY,
```
if we follow the spec to the word the genesis time doesn't take into account for the follow distance

author: paulhauner
content: Does the spec define where you‚Äôre getting the eth1 blocks from? I‚Äôd say that it‚Äôs undefined and unclear either way

author: nishant0
content:
this should be specified on how we determine 
```
eth1_timestamp
```

author: nishant0
content: yeap agreed

author: nishant0
content: that should be clarified

author: paulhauner
content: Agreed

author: donschoe
content: I can create a discussion if you like

author: paulhauner
content: I had assumed that this was the case, I should have flagged it at the time. I didn‚Äôt actually notice my assumption.

author: nishant0
content:
```
eth1_timestamp is the Unix timestamp corresponding to eth1_block_hash
```

author: nishant0
content: this should probably be changed

author: paulhauner
content: Given that we should follow deposits at follow distance, I think a configuration that sets the delay to be less than the follow distance is bound to result in skipped slots. Would need to do some more thinking to come up with a concrete statement about this, though.

author: djrtwo
content:
It's certainly unsafe to make decisions on eth1 blocks before the follow distance. Due to that, the genesis delay should probably just always be greater than the follow distance for safety.
There are a number of unwritten relationship between some of the configs and this is certainly one of them. 

I'll write it that this relationship should hold, otherwise, genesis is likely to be missed at the start.

author: nishant0
content:
<@!557201004060213248> to have quick chainstarts you probably can set the eth1 follow distance as a much smaller amount. Ex:
```
16
```
as long as the 
```
genesis_delay > eth1_follow_distance * time_per_eth1_block
```

author: djrtwo
content: yes, agreed. Will make clear the correct behaviour in the spec right now
